article.title: Understanding macrophage differentiation during space flight: The importance of ground-based experiments before space flight
funding: NIH grants AI55052, AI052206, AI088070, RR16475 and RR17686
the Terry C. Johnson Center for Basic Cancer Research and the Kansas Agriculture Experiment Station
article.abstract: In preparation for a space flight on STS-126, two in vitro culture systems were used to investigate macrophage colony stimulating factor-dependent macrophage differentiation from mouse primary bone marrow cells.

sections.introduction: Spaceflight and/or microgravity can alter the immune system at organismic levels [1, 2]as well as cellular levels [3–5].
sections.methods: Two possible hardware configurations were tested. One was the Cell Cult Bioreactor from Techshot (Formerly Space Hardware Optimization Technology, Inc. Greenville, IN) [17–19].
sections.results: We discovered that cells proliferated more in space compared to ground-incubated cells.
sections.discussion: The preflight verification tests comparing the Techshot bioreactor to FPAs prepared us for the flight.

article.insights_summary: The study investigated macrophage differentiation during space flight using two in vitro culture systems. The results showed that cells proliferated more in space compared to ground-incubated cells.
article.acknowledgments: We thank Dr. Alan Forsman for help with STS-69, -73 and -77, Michelle Pate for her help with the preflight verification tests and Nanyan Lu for help with the array data from STS-126.
